{"step_by_step_thinking": "The main outcome measure of the study would be the prevalence of HIV among female sex workers. Prevalence refers to the proportion of individuals in a population who have a specific condition or characteristic at a given point in time. In this case, the researchers are interested in determining the proportion of female sex workers who have HIV. Incidence refers to the number of new cases of a condition or characteristic that occur within a specific time period. Hazard rate refers to the rate at which individuals experience an event or condition over time. Attributable risk refers to the proportion of disease occurrence that can be attributed to a specific risk factor. While all of these measures may be of interest in the study, the main outcome measure would be the prevalence of HIV.", "answer_choice": "B"}
